entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 28, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

New York Mets @ Miami Marlins, 12:10p

Summary

The watchability math and the stakes agree: a gNERD of 17.42 tops todayâs slate, and the Mets need a win plus a Reds loss to keep playing. Itâs Sean Manaeaâs quick-working, xFIP-forward profile (xFIP- 80, 16.0s pace) against Edward Cabreraâs electricity, including the party trick of a 96.5 mph changeup. New Yorkâs tNERD (11.82) is buoyed by elite barrels, baserunning, and a trustworthy pen, and Pete Alonso just underlined the point with a double and a homer to keep this finale relevant. Miamiâs lower tNERD is largely bullpen drag, but Cabreraâs upper-90s heat and whiff-y change add fun chaos, especially as he ramps back up after a recent IL stint. Manaeaâs pNERD (9.92) suggests above-average underlying run prevention even as the Mets have flirted with a piggyback plan; expect Carlos Mendoza to have David Peterson ready if the pitch count pops. If New York leads late, note that the bullpen just locked down a shutout; if they trail, the added subplot is that this could be Alonsoâs last regular-season game in Queens colors, which only heightens the watch.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.)

Kansas City Royals @ Athletics, 12:05p

Summary

This one rides the ace: a gNERD of 14.59 is mostly a Cole Ragans ticket, with elite underlying run prevention and a fresh 10-K tune-up making Kansas City the watch side. Oakland counters with rookie lefty Brady Basso in homerâfriendly West Sacramentoâvolatility plus novelty in a park that tends to carry.

At this gNERD, weâre near the 95th percentile historically and among todayâs top games; the separator is Ragansâ pNERD (12.41), well above the usual high bar. After a midseason rotatorâcuff pause, his skill indicators stayed sharp (xERA around 2.6, FIP about 2.2), and he just punched out 10 in five innings, the kind of batâmissing profile that props up watchability even if the run prevention wobbled at times.

Basso brings a different flavor: the Aâs have used him in relief down the stretch, and the scouting report reads lowâ90s fastball with a Zitoâstyle, batâdropping curve; fun, but with limited starter track record.

Context helps: the Royals can seal a winning season with a finale win, while the Aâs are closing their first Sacramento year in a small TripleâA yard that plays lively in heat and at night. Expect KCâs top arm versus an Aâs lineup that scores but leaks runs late, a mix that explains why this gNERD sits where it does.

Minnesota Twins @ Philadelphia Phillies, 12:05p

Summary

Cristopher SÃ¡nchez has pitched like a quiet ace, and he gets an extra spark today: Trea Turner returns while Kyle Schwarber keeps stalking Ryan Howardâs franchise HR mark. With a gNERD of 12.95âwell above todayâs averageâthis profiles as a SÃ¡nchez showcase with some bonus storylines.

SÃ¡nchezâs underlying line is the draw: triple-slash run prevention built on a sub-3.00 FIP and xFIP with strong strike-throwing and few homers allowed, the kind of profile that supports his top-tier pNERD. Opposite him, Simeon Woods Richardsonâs contact quality indicators and run estimators skew the other way (FIP in the mid-4s, xFIP around five), so the mound matchup tilts hard toward Philadelphia. Team-wise, the Philliesâ tNERD pops because they pair plus bats and baserunning with watchable production, and theyâve already locked the NLâs No. 2 seedâmeaning today is less about stakes and more about rhythm. The Twinsâ case rests on a solid bullpen and the possibility they spoil a party; they blanked Philly yesterday behind newly acquired ex-Phils prospect Mick Abel, so thereâs a little fresh-trade spice in the air. If youâre triaging screens, cue this for SÃ¡nchezâs tune-up and the chance at some late-season star turns from Turner and Schwarber.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Toronto Blue Jays, 12:07p

Summary

AL East stakes meet stylistic contrast: Kevin Gausman tries to pitch Toronto to the division while Tampa counters with rookie lefty Ian Seymour, who recently muzzled these same Jays. With a gNERD of 12.72âwell above todayâs average and near the historic 75th percentileâthis grades as a clear watch.

Toronto can clinch the division with a win (they hold the tiebreaker over New York), which adds real bite to every pitch. The matchup quality holds up: the average pNERD is 6.09, with Seymour at 6.37 (xFIP- 93, quicker tempo) and Gausman at 5.81 (xFIP- 91, more deliberate), so both sit above todayâs pitching baseline. Gausman also arrives off a two-hit, 100-pitch complete-game shutout of the Astros, while Seymour spun seven innings of one-run (unearned) ball against Toronto on September 17.

Team-wise, Torontoâs 6.73 tNERD leans on plus offense and gloves (+84.4 Batting Runs, +37.8 Fielding Runs), while Tampaâs 6.53 tNERD blends elite speed (+12.8 Baserunning Runs) with a sturdier bullpen and shakier defense. That contrastâJaysâ contact/defense versus Raysâ running game and reliefâkeeps the late innings volatile if Toronto doesnât build a cushion early. Starters are slated as Seymour vs. Gausman, so plan for splitter-heavy whiffs against tempo-friendly craft.

Detroit Tigers @ Boston Red Sox, 12:05p

Summary

Both teams are already October-bound, but Detroitâs seed is still in playâand the likely matchup has shifted to Tarik Skubal vs. Lucas Giolito rather than the earlier Paddack/TBD listing. If itâs Skubal-Giolito at Fenway, bump this up your queue.

The gNERD sits at 12.10, a top-quartile score historically and above todayâs average, and itâs driven more by the team side than the mound uncertainty: Bostonâs tNERD pops thanks to elite run prevention (defense and a high-performing bullpen), while Detroit brings barrels and baserunning heat with a shakier penâexactly the kind of stylistic contrast that keeps a game lively late. The pNERD is only middling on paper (Paddack 3.47, TBD 0), but thatâs outdated context; Detroit shifted Paddack to the bullpen earlier this month. If Skubal goes, youâre upgrading to an ace whoâs spent the year missing bats at a top-tier clip with FIP-level dominance; Giolito has been a credible rebound for Boston. Layer in that the Tigers clinched but can still jockey for seeding while the Red Sox are locked in, and you get a watch that leans on smart defense vs. barrel-and-bags offenseâand possibly a marquee starter showcase if lineups hold.

Cincinnati Reds @ Milwaukee Brewers, 12:10p

Summary

A win clinches the Reds a wild card, but they have to get it against Freddy Peralta, who just crossed 200 strikeouts for the third straight year. Milwaukee already locked the NLâs top seed, yet their track-team baserunning and sharpened late innings mean this wonât feel like a formality.

With gNERD 11.23 sitting above todayâs average, the appeal leans Brewers: a big tNERD 9.61 built on elite baserunning (+2.18) and a strong bullpen (+1.11) versus a Reds tNERD of 3.37 weighed down by thin contact quality. That speed isnât theoreticalâMilwaukee set a franchise record with nine steals this yearâand it tends to keep even low-contact innings lively.

On the mound itâs Brady Singer vs. Peralta, confirmed for the finale. Peraltaâs pNERD 5.25 (xFIP- 93) plus 200+ Ks signal real bat-missing theater; Singerâs 4.23 pNERD and neutral xFIP- point to contact management, but he works quickly, which helps the watchability meter even if whiffs are modest.

Add context: Cincinnati enters tied for the last NL spot but holds the tiebreaker, so a win gets them in, while Milwaukeeâs bullpen has shifted to Abner Uribe closing and remains no picnic late. Stakes plus contrast-y styles make this a worthy click.

Texas Rangers @ Cleveland Guardians, 12:10p

Summary

Pitching and defense are the draw: Cleveland leans on an elite run-prevention machine while Texas brings slick leather and, possibly, Patrick Corbinâs veteran variance. With a gNERD of 10.88âslightly above todayâs average and a hair over the historical medianâthis profiles as a quietly worthwhile watch rather than a fireworks show.

The likely matchup is Joey Cantillo vs. Patrick Corbin, with multiple outlets listing the lefties; Cantillo offers bat-missing upside (~10 K/9 this season), while Corbinâs recent highs include eight scoreless with eight Ks, even if his underlying pNERD (4.03) says temper expectations. Clevelandâs tNERD (7.60) is fueled by a top-shelf bullpen and defense, and the Guardiansâ youth/athleticism adds pace and chaosâin a good way. Texasâs tNERD (5.13) is buoyed by plus baserunning and elite team defense, but the bats and barrels lag, and injuries to core hitters have muted the lineupâs ceiling. If youâre here for process over pyrotechnics, this is your lane: Cantilloâs extension/changeup play, Corbinâs cutter-and-command makeover, and two sturdy bullpens should keep run expectancy modest and leverage high late. Slugfest seekers can pass; connoisseurs of run prevention, tune in.

Los Angeles Dodgers @ Seattle Mariners, 12:10p

Summary

Clayton Kershawâs likely final regular-season start gives this one a builtâin narrative hook, and both clubs are already playoffâsecure, so youâre tuning in for the sendoff and the swings. Seattle has locked a firstâround bye and L.A. is fixed as the NLâs No. 3 seed, which may shorten leashes but wonât mute the theater.

The gNERD sits a tick above both the historic and todayâs averages, driven more by lively lineups than overpowering arms. L.A.âs topâtier barrels and run creation meet a Mariners offense thatâs also graded well by Batting Runs, while Seattleâs shaky fielding and merely average bullpen make late innings ripe for actionâsomething we just saw when AndrÃ©s MuÃ±oz faltered and the Dodgers struck for a ninthâinning win, capped by a KikÃ© HernÃ¡ndez double. Kershawâs pNERD is modest (average xFIPâ, low whiff rate), but pace helps the watchability, and the moment matters; this is billed as his final regularâseason start before the Dodgers pivot to a Wild Card series fronted by others. On the other side, Bryce Miller brings aboveâaverage velocity and a profile that screams varianceâsubpar xFIPâ but a big positive âLuckâ flagâexactly the kind of starter who can either surf or drown against the Dodgersâ barrel brigade.

Probables: Kershaw vs. Miller are on the board.

The result is a rivalry game where the position players carry the spectacle and any pitcher whiffs are a bonus.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 26, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

4.8 7:15p Colorado Rockies -0.8 San Francisco Giants 3.9 GermÃ¡n MÃ¡rquez 1.6 Trevor McDonald No data

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Detroit Tigers @ Boston Red Sox, 4:10p

Summary

Top watchability alert: gNERD has TigersâRed Sox at the peak of todayâs slate, and it comes with real stakes. Detroit just pulled even atop the AL Central while Boston missed a clinch, so both sides are playing for October positioning.

Kyle Harrison is the wild card that nudges the pNERD up: the lefty has been sharp since Boston brought him back, carrying a 3.58 ERA with 32 K in 32.2 IP, and heâs listed as the probable starter here, which dovetails with his fast pace and whiff-friendly profile the model likes. Casey Mize is the counter: more strike-thrower than bat-misser, but with a tidy FIP (~3.98) and a strong K/BB (~3.8), he profiles as a quality run suppressor rather than a fireworks show.

tNERD leans Boston thanks to better run prevention pieces: defense thatâs graded above average this year and a deeper late-inning mix, a contrast to Detroitâs shakier relief group flagged by the model. Add the playoff contextâDetroitâs tie atop the Central, Boston angling to finish the jobâand you get a high-skill, high-leverage watch that should move quickly and feel tense, not noisy.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.)

Recommended broadcasts: TV, Detroit Tigers (2.74); radio, Detroit Tigers (2.64)

Playoff leverage meets a pitcher-development lab: Cleveland turns to Slade Cecconi in a dead-heat division race, while Jack Leiter arrives with premium velocity and just enough chaos to keep every pitch interesting. If you like gloves, bullpens, and high-stakes reps for young arms, this is your channel-flip deterrent.

The gNERD sits at 10.86, a tick above todayâs average, because team components do the heavy lifting: Clevelandâs strong gloves and bullpen (tNERD 7.43) pair well with Texasâs own defense/basestealing profile (tNERD 5.37). On the mound, the pNERD duo is middling but contrasting: Cecconiâs underlying run prevention is better (xFIP- 97) than Leiterâs (111), while Leiter brings 97 mph heat and prospect pedigree for swing-and-miss potential even if the strikes wander. Clevelandâs stakes are realâtheyâre tied atop the AL Central and hold the head-to-head tiebreakerâso every inning is charged, and Texas arrives scuffling after a rough stretch, adding a hint of volatility without any promise of continuation. Cecconiâs path here matters too: acquired from Arizona and folded into the rotation in May, heâs been a development project with six-pitch optionality that fits Clevelandâs pitching lab ethos. All told, above-average watchability from defense, bullpen bite, and playoff pressure, even if the bats lag behind.

The foil is Hendricks (pNERD 1.97): command-forward, low whiffs, inflated xFIP, but he just spun seven shutout in his 300th career start, reminding everyone the contact-manager act can still land.

Angels tNERD (1.61) drags because of poor defense and a shaky pen, but their bats carry some theater: Mike Trout just crossed 400 homers, and Taylor Ward has been mashing, up to 36 on the year. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 25, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

9.5 3:05p Miami Marlins 5.1 Philadelphia Phillies 8.6 Janson Junk 4.5 Walker Buehler 1.0
9.5 4:05p Chicago White Sox 2.7 New York Yankees 8.4 Davis Martin 2.9 Carlos RodÃ³n 5.1

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

New York Mets @ Chicago Cubs, 4:40p

Summary

Top of the slate for watchability: rookie firebrand vs. Opening Day stalwart with real playoff leverage. gNERD loves it (17.99) and the stakes oblige: the Cubs push toward 90 wins while the Mets cling to the final NL wild card.

Nolan McLean brings a pNERD of 10.17 and the skills to match: a 95 mph fastball, quick pace, and an xFIP- around 71 in our model, plus 28 strikeouts in his first four MLB starts and a debut run that included seven straight outings of two earned or fewer. Thatâs the profile of a made-for-TV rookie ace rather than a mirage. On the other side, Shota Imanagaâs command keeps traffic light, but the 2025 story has been contact quality: a 4.78 FIP with 1.9 HR/9 means hitters must slug their way through himâsomething the Metsâ top-tier barrel rate is built to doâeven as heâs been solid at Wrigley.

Team-wise, this checks every tNERD box: New Yorkâs bats, baserunning, and a sneaky-good bullpen drive an elite 11.71, while Chicago counters with excellent defense and disruptive baserunning at 10.17. Layer in the standings pressure after the Cubsâ recent win over New York, and youâve got skill, contrast, and consequence in one tidy package.

Detroit Tigers @ Cleveland Guardians, 3:40p

Summary

High stakes, a quick-working rookie with a wicked cambio, and two above-average tNERDs make this a clear-queue-it game. Cleveland hands the ball to Parker Messick (pNERD 9.52), while Detroit is listing Keider Montero as probableâan intriguing contrast of a feel/changeup lefty versus a shorter-leash righty.

Still, Mahleâs home split is the hookâheâs been nails at Globe Life, allowing very little there this yearâwhile Oberâs xFIP- of 114 and a sizable positive Luck component suggest heâs underperformed skill-wise and could look better than his surface line.

Texas is playing out the string after elimination, but they just snapped an eight-game skid and even got a lift from fresh call-up Billy McKinney, so the vibes arenât funereal. The team NERDs add watchability in less obvious ways: the Rangers grade well in fielding and baserunning, the Twins bring an above-average bullpen, and both offenses have underwhelmed by Batting Runsâmeaning small mistakes and late-inning leverage should decide it more than slug.

Kansas City Royals @ Los Angeles Angels, 6:38p

A known quantity versus a live audition: Michael Lorenzenâs strike-throwing steadiness meets rookie lefty Mitch Farris, who beat these same Royals in his MLB debut and is trying to prove he belongs. Expect the intrigue to come from the matchup puzzle more than overpowering stuff: Kansas Cityâs contact-heavy lineup against a new look lefty, and whether the Angelsâ defense and bullpen can keep from stepping on rakes.

With a gNERD of 7.47 (below both todayâs average and the historic median), this rates as âbackground TV with upside.â Pitching drives that: Lorenzenâs pNERD is a shade below median, built on competence not whiffs, but he just logged 7.2 efficient innings in his last turn; Farris is a zero-data pNERD because of the tiny sample, yet his debut vs KC was five solid innings and his four-start slate shows a 19:9 K:BB and legit swing-and-miss even in a rough Coors outing.

Team-wise, the Royalsâ tNERD edge comes from defense and a sturdier pen, while the Angelsâ low tNERD screams volatility: loud barrels, leaky gloves, and late-inning nerves. Recent series color doesnât change thatâLAA just nipped KC behind Yusei Kikuchi and a Taylor Ward blastâbut it does hint that Angels power punishes mistakes, even for .500ish clubs. Also: the Angels are staring at another playoff-less year.

With the dayâs lowest gNERD, the model sees a lopsided watch: Seattleâs aboveâaverage tNERD (5.65) is driven by real bat speed (positive batting runs and barrels), while Colorado drags a bottomâtier tNERD (-0.92) across offense, baserunning, fielding, and bullpen. Bradley Blalockâs pNERD (1.18) is a red flag for watchabilityâhis xFIP- sits at 134 with minimal whiffs and strike throwing, the kind of profile that turns âpitcherâs gameâ into âlaunch angle lab.â On the other side, Seattle hasnât nailed down a starterâlocal listings have toggled between Emerson Hancock and Bryan Wooâwhich fits a postâclinch shuffle and makes run prevention hard to forecast.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 24, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Toronto Blue Jays, 4:07p

Summary

Top of the watchability board and it earns it: gNERD 15.73 pits Cy-caliber Garrett Crochet against the name-brand gravity of Max Scherzer, with Boston desperate for wins while Toronto tunes up minus key pieces. If youâre saving one window, this is the one.

Crochetâs elite pNERD (12.28) backs up a season of power and precisionâheâs piled up 240-plus strikeouts across nearly 200 innings with a sub-3 FIP, and heâs been on a heater (13â1 over his last 19 starts). Scherzer, meanwhile, is trying to steady things after an abbreviated, injury-tinged year that recently included a 0.2-inning, 7-run blowup; the name still pops, but the underlying run prevention hasnât. The team inputs say âwatchâ: Bostonâs high tNERD rides a sharp bullpen and plus fielding and baserunning, while Torontoâs tNERD blends elite defense with a contact-first offenseâbut the Jays are without Bo Bichette to finish the regular season, and they just lost Ty France while activating Anthony Santander. Stakes add juice: Toronto has already clinched and is jockeying for seeding, while Bostonâs margin is thin enough that every Crochet day feels like a must-have.

New York Mets @ Chicago Cubs, 5:05p

Summary

This one sits atop the watchability heap: a gNERD 15.72 thatâs above the 95th percentile historically, plus real stakes after the Mets staged a wild comeback against a Cubs team trying to halt a skid. Rookie Jonah Tongâs mystery-box arsenal meets Matthew Boydâs Wrigley-tuned precisionâyouthful whiffs versus veteran sequencing.

The appeal here is two excellent tNERDs colliding: the Mets bring top-tier thunder (barrels and NL-leading power vibes) against a Chicago club that runs the bases well and catches everything, and the contrast on the mound sweetens it. Boyd has been All-Star-caliber run prevention with a FIP around 3.10 and a notably strong home track record; if heâs in the zone early, Chicagoâs bullpen finally gets a breather. Tong, making just his fifth MLB start, offers novelty and upsideâa ride-y four-seamer paired with a revamped Vulcan-change thatâs spiking whiffsâand heâs fresh off a five-inning, eightâstrikeout scoreless start. Add in New Yorkâs late-inning punch (Nimmo, Alvarez, Alonso) and the Cubsâ urgency to stop the slide, and youâve got action in all phases even if the pNERD side is merely average. If you like stakes, swing decisions, and outfield walls tested, this is your pick.

With a gNERD of 15.41ânear the top of todayâs slate and above the 95th percentile historicallyâthis grades as must-watch. Luzardoâs pNERD (10.01) is carrying real teeth: an xFIP- of 81 with midâ90s velocity, whiffs to spare, and recent outings with doubleâdigit strikeouts, now doing it in Phillies pinstripes after the winter trade from Miami. Ryan Weathers isnât window dressing; the lefty brings 96.9 mph heat, works quickly, and sits near leagueâaverage run prevention by xFIP, enough to make this a real duel if his strike rate cooperates. Miami arrives on a sevenâgame heater after an 11âinning comeback at this park, and both bullpens grade volatile, so lateâinning entropy is firmly in play; even J.T. Realmutoâs hand scare came back clean.

Skenes vs. Greene is peak gNERDânear the top of todayâs slate and above the 95th percentile historicallyâbecause the arms dramatically outshine the bats.

Paul Skenes brings elite underlying run prevention (midâ2s FIP) with upperâ90s heat and that splinker/changeup mix that turned heads, while Hunter Greene counters with a leagueâbest fastball and newly tidy strike throwing; he just spun a oneâhit, nineâinning shutout and owns topâtier xERA/KâBB traits. Washington Nationals @ Atlanta Braves, 9:15a

A low-gNERD curiosity play: Bryce Elderâs hurry-up routine versus a rookie mystery box in Andrew Alvarez gives this NL East shrug just enough shape to peek at. If you like fast innings, soft contact, and a chance to scout a fresh lefty, this is your lane.

At 7.35, the gNERD sits well below both todayâs average and the historical median, and the team components are the drag: Washingtonâs bats, gloves, and bullpen all grade poorly while Atlantaâs tNERD is only modestly sunnier. Elder is the known quantityânearâaverage underlying run prevention (xFIP- ~98), very quick tempo, low whiffsâand heâs coming off a legitimately sharp, sevenâinning, oneârun start, even if his season contact profile still invites damage. Meanwhile, Alvarez debuted this month and remains dataâsparse; that lack of a pNERD read is part of the intrigue, not a selling point.

Storylines help: Atlantaâs riding a doubleâdigit win streak while patching around Ozzie Albiesâs hamateârelated IL stint; Washington is in talentâaudit mode, giving kids reps after injuries thinned the staff. If you tune in, do it to watch Elderâs pace and to get first impressions on Alvarezâand to see whether power bats like James Wood can interrupt the Bravesâ groove.

If you like sliders, strikeouts, and a little defensive roulette, thereâs enough here to keep the remote parked.

Kolek vs. Kikuchi is confirmed, with Kikuchi set for his 33rd start, a new personal high. On the mound, neither pNERD pops (Kolek 4.00; Kikuchi 3.71), but there are hooks: Kolek works fast (17.5s) with nearâaverage run prevention (xFIPâ 98) and just logged 8 efficient innings with a careerâhigh eight Ks; Kikuchi brings real velocity (94.8 mph) and a leagueâaverage xFIPâ (103), even if the command wanders. The Angels punch out in bulkâover 1,400 team strikeoutsâwhich gives Kolek some punchâup potential despite a modest SwStr%. On the team side, the Royalsâ watchability leans on defense (+14.5 fielding runs) and a competent âpen, while the Angelsâ tNERD is dragged down by dreadful fielding (â54.9) and a leaky bullpen. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 23, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

New York Mets @ Chicago Cubs, 4:40p

Summary

Todayâs gNERD king spotlights a surging rookie with real bat-missing weapons versus a star-laden lineup playing for its season. The Cubs are already secure, while the Mets are neck-and-neck (and behind on tiebreakers) for the NLâs final Wild Card, so every pitch has teeth.
Cade Horton brings mid-90s heat with a sweeper/changeup combo that drives whiffs, and his underlying line (around a mid-3s FIP with a long run of stingy outings) backs the surface shine; think zone-filling poise rather than max-effort chaos. The Cubsâ style props the watchability, too: elite run prevention and rangy gloves plus an aggressively opportunistic running game tend to turn balls in play into action. The Mets counter with thunder â a top-tier barrel profile here meets the âFab Fourâ of Alonso, Soto (flirting with 40â40), Lindor, and Nimmo, which is why their tNERD hums. David Peterson grades as above-average by estimators (xFIP- in the black), but heâs recently leaked big innings, the kind that up the drama and bullpen involvement. One subplot: Kyle Tucker has been nursing a calf; if heâs limited, that dings Chicagoâs middle-order thump. All told, a top-of-the-day gNERD with playoff stakes, contrasting identities, and a rookie making his case is easy appointment viewing.

Detroit Tigers @ Cleveland Guardians, 3:40p

Summary

A division race, a buzzsaw ace, and a bullpen that never blinks: this is the watch. Tarik Skubal versus a surging Guardians staff, with Cleveland holding the tiebreaker and Detroit clinging to a oneâgame lead, is stakes plus stuff.

Skubalâs pNERD is elite and his profile backs it: upperâ90s heat, topâtier xFIP-, and strike/whiff rates that make hitters defensive; heâs also shredded Cleveland this year (32 K, 2 BB in 22 IP, including a CGSO) and was cleared after a brief ribâcage scare. Gavin Williams brings midâ90s velocity and recent form, including 11 scoreless innings versus Detroit and a strong lastâsixâstart run, even if his underlying run estimators sit closer to average.

The team ingredients explain the big gNERD: Detroitâs bats bring barrels and baserunning pop, while a shakier bullpen adds lateâinning chaos; Clevelandâs offense is lighter but pairs elite defense with a relief corps thatâs been a feature since last year. With the Guardians riding a rotation tear and the standings razorâthin, every pitch mattersâespecially because Clevelandâs pen rarely coughs up a lead.

Given Skubalâs topâofâtheâday pNERD and a gNERD well above the historical 95th percentile, prioritize this one.

Miami Marlins @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:45p

Summary

Two reasons this pops: Cristopher SÃ¡nchezâs run as an xFIP bully meets Edward Cabreraâs powerâstuff return from the IL. And with Philly already divisionâclinched and angling for the NLDS bye, the stakes are real enough to keep the throttle open.

At 15.72, the gNERD sits near the top of todayâs slate and above the 95th percentile historically, and the shape explains why: SÃ¡nchezâs pNERD (9.5) is fueled by a 69 xFIPâ and plus strike throwing, the kind of profile that recently produced eight scoreless against Detroit and a season line thatâs been worthy of his preâseason extension. Cabrera (8.14 pNERD) returns from an elbow strain with 97âish heat and that occasionally ludicrous midâ90s changeup; he punched out 10 Braves in late August and has the raw stuff to turn a lineup over even if the command wanders.

Teamwise, Phillyâs higher tNERD (8.45) shows up in better bats and real baserunning value, and the Duranâfortified bullpen adds lateâinning octane if needed. Miamiâs younger, lowâpayroll roster adds some chaos, but its bullpen drags. With Trea Turner nursing a hamstring, the Phillies have still been fine to prioritize rest while they lock down that bye.

Playoff-tuned Toronto just clinched the ALâs first postseason berth and rolls in behind Kevin Gausmanâs two-hit, 100-pitch shutout; thatâs a pretty good watchability starter kit. Boston counters with Lucas Giolito, freshly past the 140-inning threshold that unlocked his opt-out, adding a contract subplot to a series Toronto currently leads 7â3.

The probable arms further tilt the watchability: Bryce Miller has worked back from elbow trouble and has pitched to a FIP in the midâ5s this yearâvolatile but with strikeout upsideâwhile Colorado counters with recent call-up McCade Brown (TJ in 2023), who only debuted a few weeks ago and is still getting stretched out. Seattleâs bullpen depth has been tested (Gregory Santos out; Bryan Woo banged up), adding a little late-inning coin-flip energy.

Relative to todayâs slate (average gNERD 11.43), this sits low; but if youâre prioritizing power vs. a thin staff and a contender tune-up, itâs a worthwhile watch.

Boston has owned the matchup lately (eight straight, 10â2 this season), so the real question is whether Tampa can manufacture enough chaos to flip it. gNERD 12.78 sits in the top quartile of historic games and near the top of todayâs slate, driven more by team traits than the mound matchup: Boston pairs plus baserunning, stout defense, and a top bullpen, while Tampa brings elite baserunning but light barrels and errorâprone gloves. Early is the intrigue engine â 11 Ks in five scoreless in his debut, with a minors rÃ©sumÃ© that included a 40% strikeout rate and 1.73 FIP in a DoubleâA sample â so the âstuffâ is real even if the bigâleague sample isnât. Summary

A playoff-chasing Cleveland run-prevention machine meets a Twins starter fresh off his best swing-and-miss night; if you like tidy, tense baseball, this oneâs worth your eyeballs. The Guardians have rattled off 10 straight and sliced the AL Central gap to a single game after a doubleheader shutout sweep in Minneapolis, raising the stakes nicely.

With a gNERD of 10.64, this sits slightly above the historical median and around the middle of todayâs slate, but the ingredients are appealing: Clevelandâs superior tNERD (7.41) is built on an elite bullpen (+60 runs) and plus defense (+24), while the Twinsâ more modest tNERD (4.82) still hides a sturdy pen. Joey Cantilloâs better-than-average xFIP- (90) and brisk tempo (17.7s) underpin a pNERD edge over Simeon Woods Richardson, and heâs recently spun 8+ scoreless vs. KC and punched out seven at Fenway.

Woods Richardsonâs raw pNERD lags (xFIP- 117), but he just struck out 11 Yankees over six scoreless, so the whiffs are real even if the peripherals arenât fully sold.

Clevelandâs bats rate poorly by run value and barrels, which, paired with two competent bullpens and Minnesotaâs recent zeroes, points to a lower-scoring watch where sequencing, defense, and late relief decide itâand that can be plenty fun.

Rookie vs. metronome makes for sneaky-watchable baseball: Toronto hands the ball to Trey Yesavage, fresh off a franchise-debut record 9 strikeouts, to stop a skid, while Michael Wacha tests whether savvy can outfox swing-and-miss. The gNERD sits near the historical median, but the plot points are timely enough to keep a thumb off the remote.

Yesavageâs second look comes after five punchout-filled innings that doubled as a club debut record, the kind of pNERD mystery box (0.00) that can spike a gameâs fun factor on contact. Toronto needs it, having produced just three runs across four games with one total at-bat with RISP in this set, and now juggling the rotation after Chris Bassitt hit the IL. Wachaâs pNERD is modest (3.40) with an xFIP- of 109, and heâs coming off a concussion-return clunker (7 R, 2 2/3 IP), though he previously cruised eight innings of one-run ball vs. these Jays. Kansas City still has a pulse, with Bobby Witt Jr. and Vinnie Pasquantino powering recent wins and Pasquantino riding a heater. With Torontoâs better tNERD (7.17 to 4.46) and a rookie with whiffs to spare, this is a mid-tier gNERD (10.01) game lifted by meaningful stakes and the allure of discovery.

San Diego Padres @ Chicago White Sox, 11:10a

Summary

PadresâWhite Sox is a âbring your bullpenâ watch: San Diegoâs playoff push meets Chicagoâs rebuild, with Michael King and Sean Burke more supporting actors than headliners. Itâs mid-tier by gNERD (8.11), pulled down by a low pNERD duo, but Padres urgency and a soft White Sox lineup keep it watchable.

Kingâs pNERD (3.85) reflects average run prevention (xFIP- 97) and modest bat-missing, and heâs still ramping after a September IL return; he even ate some lumps at Citi Field last week. Burkeâs pNERD (2.30) tracks with a shaky run estimators profile (xFIP- 117) and traffic (1.47 WHIP), the kind of mix that can force early bullpen cameos. If that happens, advantage Padres: their relief corps just locked down the previous game while Adrian Morejon nabbed the win.

Macro-wise, San Diegoâs tNERD (7.30) tops Chicagoâs (2.77) and the standings explain why: Padres are 84-71 and chasing October; the Sox are 58-97 and short-handed (Luis Robert Jr. out), while Xander Bogaerts is also sidelined. Against a Chicago offense that ranks near the bottom by AVG/SLG, even Kingâs contact-leaning approach can play. Net: below todayâs average gNERD, but the playoff stakes, a bullpen edge, and a favorable matchup nudge it onto the screen.

Los Angeles Angels @ Colorado Rockies, 12:10p

Summary

This is the lowest gNERD on the board today, but it still comes with two decent hooks: Mike Trout just joined the 400-homer club, and Kyle Freelandâs added sweeper has given him a modest whiff bump. If youâre hunting for chaos, Coors plus two thin bullpens is a reasonable bet even when the watchability math shrugs.

The model dings this matchup because both tNERDs are underwater (Rockies deeply so), with Coloradoâs bats, defense, baserunning, and bullpen all grading poorly; that last item is watchable in its own way when late innings get rubbery. The Angels at least barrel the ball (excellent barrel-rate component), while their fielding and relief work drag. On the mound, rookie Caden Dana is an unknown in NERD terms (pNERD 0), but heâs a 21-year-old top prospect whoâs bounced between Triple-A and the bigs this yearânovelty points if you like scouting in real time.

Freelandâs overall run prevention hasnât wowed, but the sweeper has been a real addition, and his 2025 FIP sits closer to âserviceableâ than the surface stats suggest. If Troutâs milestone hangover includes another loud swing and Dana finds early strikes, this clears its low bar; otherwise youâre watching to see which bullpen blinks first.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 20, 2025

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:05p

Summary

Todayâs gNERD headliner (14.25) offers contrasting thrills: Bostonâs quick-strike, bullpen-backed outfit vs. Tampa Bayâs run-happy chaos. With Kyle Harrisonâs youthful heat and pace against Adrian Houserâs contact-management act, thereâs motion baked into nearly every inning.

Harrisonâs pNERD 8.35 tracks with the ingredients you want to watchâmidâ90s velocity and a brisk 16.1s tempo that keeps the camera cutting; Houserâs 4.16 and leagueâaverage underlying run prevention (xFIP around 3.9) hint at more balls in play than whiffs. Bostonâs tNERD 8.93 is powered by an elite bullpen (+1.62) and real defensive value (+1.11), the sort of leverage-and-run-prevention cocktail that tightens late frames. Tampa Bayâs tNERD 7.06 is TVâfriendly in a different way: topâtier baserunning (+1.92) paired with shaky gloves (â1.24) and a solid pen (+0.74) means traffic, gambles and mistakesâi.e., entertainment. Storyline spice: Boston just took the opener and has beaten Tampa Bay seven straight, while the Rays hand the ball to Houser after an uneven acclimation.

Among todayâs slate (1.63â14.25), this sits on the summit; historically, itâs near the 95thâpercentile tierâworthy of your first screen.

Washington Nationals @ New York Mets, 1:10p

Summary

A must-see rookie vs. a post-surgery power arm, with a win-now Mets lineup looming â this one has juice. At gNERD 14.02, it sits near the top of todayâs slate and around the historic 95th percentile, so the watchability signal is loud.

Nolan McLeanâs 9.64 pNERD is backed by real indicators: a tidy xFIP- (73) and brisk pace (16.8s), plus a month-old debut thatâs become a 1.19 ERA run with record-setting company for a Mets rookie. Cade Cavalli (5.76 pNERD) brings 97 mph and the intrigue of a 2025 return from March 2023 Tommy John â the stuff is there, the consistency less so. The matchup itself appears set: McLean vs. Cavalli for the first time. Team-wise, the Metsâ hefty 11.59 tNERD rides thunder (barrels, batting runs) and a capable pen, while Washingtonâs 1.05 tNERD is dragged by defense and relief â and the Natsâ error-strewn opener didnât help. Add stakes: New Yorkâs in a tight wild-card race, which elevates every pitch.

Shane Bieberâs high-end pNERD (9.51) vs. a rookie revelation makes this a prime watch, especially with Toronto seeking order after Kansas Cityâs 27-hit, 20â1 deluge.
Noah Cameron works fast and throws strikes, and he draws a glove-forward Jays club that turns balls in play into outs.

At gNERD 13.45, this sits near the top of todayâs slate and in the historical upper tier. Bieberâs profile is appointment viewing: a 65 xFIP- with a brisk pace, plus a solid track record against this opponent; heâs also the right antidote after Torontoâs bullpen absorbed the blowout while KCâs starter went 7â. Cameronâs rookie year has been legitimately good, and while his underlying run prevention is closer to average (xFIP- ~99), the tempo and age-driven upside keep the pNERD afloat. Torontoâs tNERD edge comes from real defense and capable bats, but theyâre doing it without Bo Bichette; meanwhile, KC just lost plus-defender Kyle Isbel to the IL. Net: tune in for Bieberâs whiffs, pace from both sides, and the subplot of whether the Jaysâ run prevention tidies up last nightâs mess.

Relative to todayâs slate (avg gNERD 10.18) and historical medians, this sits a shade low because the average pNERD (3.61) is dragged by xFIP- marks that donât scream dominance (Mazur 124, Leiter 111), though Leiterâs velocity pop helps. Leiterâs story remains compelling: 97â98 with new two-seam/changeup additions, but recent command wobbles (and even a costly throwing error) underline the ride. Miami just nicked Texas in extras, a reminder the Rangers are wobbling in the race and that chaos is firmly on the menu. Mazur has bounced between starts and bulk duty since his June return to the majorsâuseful novelty, uneven outcomes. Expect more traffic than whiffs, a brisker Mazur tempo early versus Leiterâs slower pace, and plenty of balls in play to test Texasâ gloves.

gNERD 1.63 sits well below both todayâs average and the historical median, with tNERDs that scream âproceed at your own riskâ (Angels 1.40; Rockies -0.89). The arms donât rescue it: pNERDs of 1.86 (Hendricks) and 0.89 (MÃ¡rquez) track with below-average underlying skill, led by xFIP- marks of 117 and 126 and minimal whiff rates. Hendricksâ 86 mph profile and tiny SwStr% invite balls in play; MÃ¡rquez is just back from a biceps issue and hasnât missed many bats since returning. If you like contact and baserunning bedlam, Coorsâ elevated BABIP environment (.332 since 2015) reliably inflates both.

If you need a storyline, Colorado just avoided matching the 2024 White Sox and still needs wins to dodge the 1962 Metsâ loss mark, while the Angels arrive on an eight-game slide. The Angels at least bring barrels (10.6%), but dreadful fielding and spotty bullpens on both sides point toward high-variance mess rather than crisp pitching. Hendricks did spin seven scoreless his last time out, but this venue punishes optimism.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on September 19, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:35p

Summary

Top gNERD on the slate, and it earns it: ace-level Garrett Crochet (pNERD 12.26, xFIP- 62) squares off with a restored Drew Rasmussen at the Raysâ temporary outdoor digs, where Bostonâs elite bullpen meets Tampa Bayâs track team. If you like whiffs plus stolen-base chaos with late-inning leverage, this one checks every box. By our model this gameâs gNERD is 17.32, the dayâs highest and well above the historical 95th percentile, and the matchup brings real storylines with it: Crochet, now locked up long-term in Boston, has paired upper-90s heat with strike- and swing-miss rates that scream ace; Rasmussen, back from his internal-brace comeback and under a two-year deal, has been efficient more than flashy. With Sox tNERD strength coming from defense and a top-shelf bullpen, the Raysâ counter is speed; theyâve been swiping bags in bunches and just rode Chandler Simpson (and steady Yandy DÃ­az) in a shutout of Toronto. The venue twist matters, too: Tampa Bay is hosting at George M. Steinbrenner Field this season, adding some outdoor variability to a club built on run prevention and legs.

Milwaukee Brewers @ St. Louis Cardinals, 5:15p

Summary

Triple-digits versus guile: Jacob Misiorowski, the rookie who no-hit St. Louis for five innings in his debut, squares off again with Sonny Gray, who just punched out eight Brewers last week.
Milwaukeeâs sprint toward the division flag meets a shorthanded Cardinals lineup, with Willson Contreras done for the year.

At a gNERD of 15.80, this lands above the 95th percentile of historical games and near the top of todayâs slate, and the ingredients check out: a high-octane pNERD duel (Misiorowski 10.21; Gray 6.97) plus a large tNERD edge for Milwaukee (9.72 to 4.69). Misiorowskiâs appeal is obviousâhe averages 99-plus with top-of-era perceived velocity (fastball 101.3 mph; a slider that looks like mid-90s), which plays beautifully against a St. Louis offense thatâs been thinning and underperforming. Gray isnât just âveteran savvyâ; his underlying run estimators have outpaced the surface, and he just held Milwaukee to two runs over five in their latest meeting, giving this real counterpunch potential. Add Milwaukeeâs elite baserunning and deep bullpen (both strong tNERD components) against a Cards club trying to manufacture runs, and the watchability case is strong: power stuff, contrasting styles, and stakes. If you like velocity art, Misiorowski alone is worth the click.
